author: {'steamid': '76561198044574299', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 177, 'last_played': 1709465414}
review:
Not worth your time and your money.

Story is kind of what a schoolboy would do who is overzealous about shooting in Afghanistan. Maybe it would have been better if there wouldn't be a try of a story. No bonding with the characters, the theme, just shoot.

Characters are not really exist, rather than targets and not targets. No emphasis on main character, no antagonist, no allies (just soldiers who you don't shoot), no mentor, no love interest, totally nothing. Main charcter is just there because... I guess he loves to shoot.

Though there are various scenes, there is no such thing as an atmosphere. Go shoot, go shoot, the thing is the same, just the background is different.

Visuals are okay-ish. Since it is a rail shooter, not an FPS, it delivers enough. You would shoot all the time so no trouble lamenting the blandness or ugliness of the scenery.

The audio is on par with the visuals. Comrades would talk all the time, but you can't stop to listen. Main character always says hooah, whenever moves around obstacles, enemies are strangely mute.

Not the worst game, but if you want a rail shooter, grab something else.

review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028570547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2563, 'playtime_forever': 345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1701055299}
review:
"Heavy Fire: Afghanistan" ist ein First-Person Rail-Shooter.

Im Grunde ist "Heavy Fire: Afghanistan" ein aufgeblähtes "Moorhuhn". Wir schießen mit der linken Maustaste und laden mit der rechten nach. Haben wir einen Screen abgearbeitet werden wir automatisch wie auf Schienen zum nächsten Screen gebracht, auf dem neue Gegner warten, die allerdings nicht in der Lage sind einen Positionswechsel zu machen, sondern aus den immer gleichen Positionen feuern.

 Immerhin kommen später auch Gegner mit Maschinengewehren, kleinere gepanzerte Fahrzeuge und sogar Hubschrauber als Gegner hinzu, so daß zumindest ein wenig Abwechslung besteht. Nach jeweils zwei Leveln können wir sogar einen Upgrade-Punkt in eine neue Hauptwaffe, mehr Magazine, mehr Granaten oder eine bessere Schutzausrüstung investieren. 

Wir haben ein modernes Gewehr als Hauptwaffe und eine Pistole mit unendlicher Munition als Notwaffe sowie eine geringe Zahl an Handgranaten. Gegen Hubschrauber wird uns dann automatisch eine Bazooka in die Hand gedrückt. 

Wir sind übrigens als heldenhafter US-Soldat, der die Gegner im Dutzend umnietet in Afghanistan unterwegs. Eine kritische oder auch nur realistische Haltung zum US-Krieg sucht man hier vergebens. 

Das Schießen funktioniert dabei simpel und direkt, eben ähnlich wie bei "Moorhuhn". Und in gewisser Weise macht das auch kurze Zeit Spaß, denn mechanisch ist das alles in Ordnung. Grafik und Sound bleiben allerdings auf ziemlich unterdurchschnittlichem Niveau. Das Ganze wird dann allerdings doch nach relativ kurzer Zeit repetitiv und langweilig.  

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
5/10 Atmosphäre
-/10 Story
6/10 Grafik
6/10 Sound
6/10 Spielmechanik
5/10 Balancing
6/10 Spielspass 

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Moorhuhn in Afghanistan.

[h1][b]6/10 Gesamtwertung

review:
Своих денег игра точно стоит, особенно если соскучились по тирам (к сожалению сегодня этот некогда популярный жанр незаслуженно забыт). Что понравилось и не понравилось:

+ разные уровни в разном окружении
+ неплохая графика
+ дадут и на танке покататься, и на хамви, и на вертушке полетать
+ выбор вариантов прокачки
+ взрывающиеся бочки, баллоны с газом

+ возможность прятаться в укрытия

- нет серьезных штрафов за дружественный огонь

В целом поиграть можно, на безрыбье и рак - рыба. Тиров в магазине практически раз два и обчелся, а этот не такой уж и плохой. Я даже прошел его раза три.

review:
Heavy Fire: Afghanistan — в усіх сенсах «класичний» рейковий шутер. Сюжет, ігролад, музика, все чудово.

Сюжет
Класика фільмів 2000-х про американський морпіхів. Американці на Арбамсах, Хамві та Апачах, мають нищити десятки афганських терористів,  які мають лише АК-74, старі БТР та МІ-14. Все це в горах, арабських містах та печерних бункерах. Ностальгія в її гарному розумінні.

Ігролад
Рейковий шутер з нотками інтерактиву і гарними катсценами. Гарно зроблено, що від місії до місії, дійсно стає важче все встигати й швидко всі знищувати. Разом з тим в режимі ветерану, посилення складності не відчутно. Також приємно, що для цього року в грі є руйнація обьєкт для знищення прикриттів чи чинити шкоду ворогам.

Виглядає
Графіка відповідає стандартам часу видання гри. VFX середній, повеселило анімації смерті в ворогів. 

Звучить
Звукова доріжка крута, тут без зайвих слів. Звуки ж стрільби та вибухів іноді звучать дивно, особливо в гелікоптерів. Також фразу в разі френдлі фаєру, я запам’ятаю на довго, бо ТЕКІН ФАЕР!

Глючить
Ні, але в мене чомусь меню в Full HD, а сама гра в віконці HD.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108040263', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1670714357}
review:
Much like its sequel, Shattered Spear, this game is a decent shooter for what it is and it does look pretty good. Sometimes the screen is utter chaos with how much is on it, but it's still good fun. However, there's massive differences between this one and the sequel.

For starters, unlike the sequel, enemies have a small ! pop up when they're about to hit you, which is a mercy compared to the later game as you can actually tell who is going to take a chunk out of your health and where. But then the gameplay is slower, or at least feels it. Every time I clicked to fire, it felt like there was a delay, which is kinda bad given I'm supposed to be using a machine gun. And then there's the marines, who you will most likely shoot by accident. On one hand, you only lose 50 points shooting them in this, it's not an instant game over, but on the other there's a LOT more marines in this game, meaning you'll likely make a number of mistakes.

The game feels easier than its sequel and it looks just as good. I get the feeling I'll see this one through quicker, though the levels will likely be slower in general. It certainly feels like they were getting to grips with the idea of a rail shooter, but if this is their first attempt (as I can't be sure it is) then they did a bang up job all the same.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148572123', 'num_games_owned': 179, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1656782009}
review:
To preface, i really wish Steam had a neutral review score because mine is towards the negative :/
Honestly as a fan of on-rails shooter games, i feel maybe some value could be had, if you get it on sale, for the unfortunate reason that sadly the genre is unrepresented on PC, and this is one of the very few titles officially released for it that will run on modern computers.
Having said that, the game just isn't that much fun. I really wanted to like it, i gave it an earnest try, but at best you'll be wishing you'd be playing something more engaging like Time Crisis or the many SEGA "light gun" arcade games, and at worst you'll be left with a poor image of what the whole genre is like. I understand this is a budget title, but even so, you should be able to fully make a rail-shooter on a budget while still keeping the gameplay fun. To start off, you have a cover system somewhat similar to the Crisis Zone / Raging Storm / Time Crisis games, except it doesn't play as much of an important role as it does in those games. To its' credit tho, this system offers often 2 to 3 covers to hide behind in a scene, giving it a bit variety and strategy for you to play around with, for example, being able to shoot certain enemies FROM the cover site while being protected by enemies that are not visible at that particular viewpoint.  The gunshots feel unsatisfying and the enemies look bland and often blend with the background, there isn't much in the way of making them stick out a bit more. This would be fine if it was a conscious decision, but it seems more like bad design, just as other poor visual design choices can make the gameplay confusing instead of purposefully challenging (there are some really aggressive sunlight bloom effects that pretty much blind you from seeing some enemies, and there is no reason for your gun to actually be on the screen at all times in this type of game, which sometimes block the view of enemies to your far right unintentionally)
There isn't much variety here to make things gratifying or worth coming back time again to replay it, i found myself somewhat bored by the 7th mission. You can level up your ammo, reload speed and weapon every 2 missions, but even so, there are only a handful of weapons available, your handgun, the machinegun and grenades. This isn't much different from time crisis, except again, here it is implemented poorly. Sometimes an enemy will almost disappear into the background and you will be left wondering where he is, it kind of becomes a pixel hunt of sorts before you shoot him. You have exploding barrels but their placement is sometimes iffy, there are quick time events but they rarely evoke much excitement. This is my main problem with the game, it is promising at first, and great on paper, but the action never really picks up. You have your turret sections which are fun, but eventually things don't get much more fun and the game just becomes stale.
The destruction of the enviroment seems to be spread thin and far between too. This doesn't help a sense of action.
If it is on sale, you REALLY are a diehard rail shooter fan, played every other game available or can't get the other rail shooters because of budget reasons or due to them being on console, then i guess give it a try. For the price, you could do worse.
Otherwise, i have to say you'd be better off staying clear of this one.
I easily got about an hour worth of fun out of it, and for some people, at the right price, that may be alright. I don't hate the game, but that's the thing, i am a bit frustrated that it is somewhat mediocre since it had potential to be better.
It is worth noting that this first came out in 2011, mainly for the wii and ps3, and as another reviewer pointed out, this is a bit of a badly optimized port of the console version. Unfortunately the graphics were substandard by 2011, and perhaps the game was more bearable with motion controls and the gun add-on to mimic a light gun. That said, there is no reason why a good light gun shooter would not be fun to play without a mouse, i grew up playing virtua cop 2 and house of the dead with a mouse back in the 90's with their respective PC ports, and the gameplay still held up. So it is not entirely the reason to blame for boring gameplay.
The level variety is nice at least, you go from deserts to urban villages, to caves, to forests, i found this to be interesting!The ambience of the enviroments are kinda nice aswell despite them being a bit low res and rough around the edges.

review:
[h3]Heavy Fire: Afghanistan[/h3]
[u]Egoshooter[/u]

Der Afghanistan Feldzug der Amerikaner. Du spielst einen GI, der stets an der Spitze der Truppe ins Gefecht stürmt - und das auf eine ungewohnte Art: Nicht der Spieler bewegt sich, sondern das Spiel ! Als ich erstmals davon gelesen habe, konnte ich mir nicht so richtig etwas darunter vorstellen, aber natürlich wollte ich es wissen und hab mich gleich mal ins Spiel gestürzt...

Jeder größere Abschnitt wird mit einem Video gestartet. Das passt eigentlich immer gut in ein Spiel, vor allem wenn sie gut gemacht sind - mir haben sie jedenfalls gefallen. Die Vertonung ist amerikanisch (klar, was sonst ?), es werden aber auch Untertitel in deutsch angeboten, falls man der Geschichte folgen will. Wie ich finde, sollte das der Mindeststandard sein, will man sein Spiel in Deutschland verkaufen.

Die Steuerung: Da ich mit Tastatur und Maus gespielt habe, kann ich leider nichts zum Controller sagen, aber möglicherweise ist diese Art der Steuerung vorzuziehen. Dennoch kam ich mit WASD sehr gut zurecht (+ E für die Handgranaten bzw. Raketen). Während also das Spiel wie ein Film abläuft und meistens stoppt wenn Gegner auftauchen, kann man sich je nach Situation und Deckungsmöglichkeit(en) mit WASD in Sicherheit ducken. Zielen und schießen erledigt man mit der Maus, ganz oldschool. Dabei ist die Steuerung genau und flott und in der Kombination mit der Deckung lassen sich die Angreifer gut ins Visier nehmen. Gelegentlich stoppt das Spiel aber auch nicht, dann heißt es im Laufen/Rennen zu agieren, was oft erstmal ins Auge geht, da man beim ersten Versuch nicht damit rechnet. Aber so ist es ein interessanter Mix geworden. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2795264420
Wenn man allerdings mit Panzer oder Hubschrauber unterwegs ist, dann erübrigt sich die Deckung. Dann reicht es, nur zu schießen - man muss nur die mögliche Überhitzung der Waffe beachten.

An diese Art des Spiels muss man sich erst gewöhnen, weil alles irgendwie anders funktioniert, aber ich hatte großen Spaß dabei, eben weil es was anderes ist, hatte ich doch teilweise eine Art interaktiven Film und teilweise einen gewohnten Shooter. Ich würde gerne mehr davon spielen.

Mitten in der Kampagne wurde der Fortschritt nicht mehr gespeichert, erst wieder ganz am Ende, wenn man als Rekrut alle Abschnitte bestanden hat. Hört man mittendrin mal auf, muss man also alles ab dem letzten Speicherpunkt bis zum Ende der Kampagne noch einmal spielen, egal wo man gerade war. Das hat mich sehr gestört, zumal auch beim nächsten Spielneustart der Speicherstand dann doch wieder der alte ist (wie der in Satz 1).

Die Art des Spiels, d.h. die Fortbewegung,  war mir neu und daher eine sehr interessante Erfahrung. Ich empfand das Spiel dadurch als innovativ, es sah auch gut aus und war prima vertont, Videosequenzen inclusive. Und da es auch nicht teuer ist, kann ich es jedem, der gerne rumballert, ruhigen Gewissens empfehlen.

review:
Now, I bought this game shortly after I visited an arcade and saw some on-the-rails shooters.  So yes, I knew what I was getting myself into.  While I don't regret purchasing this game...it wasn't exactly a good experience. The game is bad.  Period.
Graphics:  Eh
Story: If there was a story, I already forgot it.
Voice Acting:  Too whimsical to take the game seriously, your typical "constant war lingo" shooter.  And no, it's not the kind of "it's so bad that it's good" kind of voice acting.

Now, all of that would be forgivable if this next thing was at LEAST good...Gameplay...

The gameplay was atrocious, and made the game a slog to go through.  First off, my most hated thing in on-the-rails shooters:  limited ammo.  Sure you have a secondary with infinite ammo but with people with ocd, seeing ammo storage drain just sucks.  Secondly, the aiming sucked.  Your rifle basically 1-shots enemies (thankfully) and pistol either 1 or 2 shots them.  The thing that I hate about the aiming is that it "stutters" so instead of your cursor gliding along smoothly and easily, your crosshairs may just spontaneously get stuck on something.  Also, the cover system...yeah it doesn't protect you from all enemies...

Important to note:  I play on mouse and keyboard, although apparently there's a console controller option but I haven't tried that.

Overall:  It's no wonder why less than 10% of the people who own this game have even made it to the last mission.  It's a miserable game to play, buy it if it's on sale or in a bundle or something like that.

review:
[h1]Hodnocení 4/10,  Splněné Achievementy 27 z 27,  [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34526713/]Curator[/url] [/h1]

Heavy Fire: Afghanistan  - on-rail střílečka - tedy v hře jen střílíte své cíle, sbíráte náboje a lékárničky, mapou se pohybujete “jakoby po kolejích.” Lidé zvyklí jen na FPS s volným pohybem, více zbraněmi a více hratelnostními prvky, ruce pryč, hra není vůbec pro vás. Pravdou je, že vývojář se nepokoušel tuto skutečnost skrýt, takže pokud si přečtete recenzi od někoho, kdo na to nadává, pravděpodobně mu chybí dovednost porozumění textu.  

Příběh se odehrává kolem amerického vojáka, který věří, že dokáže udělat cokoli na čem opravdu záleží, když na Afghánce střílí v jejich vlastní zemi, trochu klišé, ale nic nezvládnutelného. 

Hra je krátká a skýtá pouze dvanáct misí, každá z nich je dlouhá asi pět minut. Dokonce ani poslední boss, vás nezdrží déle než deset minut. I přes krátkou délku misí, se hraní z větší části opakuje. Hra postrádá něco “navíc”, je to prázdné a poměrně nudné. Kvůli repetetivnosti hře ubírám bod a spíše ji nedoporučuji, vyjma lovců Achievementů.

review:
[h1]Описание:[/h1]
Рельсовый тир про то как США демократию в Афганистан приносили. Больше десятка довольно продолжительных уровней, прокачка оружия (между уровнями), красочная графика и кат сцены. Тиры вообще редкий жанр и редко встречаются, а этот прям прошел с удовольствием. И на танке дают поездить и на самолете полетать и даже с базуки пострелять. Миссии разнообразные и интересные. Не заметил даже как игру прошел. После прохождения можно пройти еще раз на сложности Veteran, но это уже без меня. Огорчило, что пришлось шаманить с файлами игры. Мне игра понравилась.

I recommend it if you know what you are buying. Heavy Fire: Afghanistan is a really short FPS on rails (I think it can be finish in two hours, I left the game a long time open and lost the account, but each level lasts for 4 to 8 minutes), with a cliche story (war against terrorism exploited a million times), has good graphics and a very varied difficulty (enemies die with ONE SHOT, but sometimes there are MANY enemies in a row). Worth buying (mainly on sale) to spend some time, if you do not want to play anything too quiet, but also not very busy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157453094', 'num_games_owned': 170, 'num_reviews': 180, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1584823511}
review:
Excellent arcade style rail shooter combines the explosive war setting of the Call Of Duty games with the fast-paced fun of Virtua Cop. Having played some light gun shooters such as Time Crisis, House Of The Dead and Aliens: Extermination in the arcades as well as a home console version of the Mad Dog McCree games, I felt right at home with Heavy Fire: Afghanistan.

You play as an American soldier in Afghanistan and you are tasked with blowing away hundreds of insurgents in every mission. The levels are very creative and you never feel like you are just doing the same thing over and over again. In one mission, you are in a tank, in another you are in a helicopter and I particularly enjoyed the stage that has you search through a network of caves. There is a cover system as sometimes you will be able to hide from enemy attacks. You also have to shoot ammo boxes and health packs dotted around each stage. You can upgrade your gun, your health etc... as you progress through the game. In terms of graphics, they are not amazing but they are perfectly acceptable. After a tweak to the sensitivity, I found the controls to be very responsive.

If you are looking for literally non-stop action then I highly recommend you play Heavy Fire: Afghanistan.

Gameplay: 8.5/10
Graphics: 6.5/10 (for the time)
Controls: 8/10
Replay Value: 7.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197982504799', 'num_games_owned': 4250, 'num_reviews': 2871, 'playtime_forever': 291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1535604060}
review:
Афганистан. Огневой рубеж - именно под таким названием, выходил сей тир у нас. Так что кому надо, возможно в инете, есть локализация. Сама игра, очередной проходной, польский тир. Кстати, первая версия на ПК, вышла в 2011 году, а не в 2014 как указано в Стиме.

[h1]Сюжет.[/h1]
Что будет если скрестить польских разработчиков с линейным тиром, и Афганистаном? Правильно! Адски унылая, пафосная, пропаг@ндонская агитка, о том как могучая американская армия, надирает задницы, местным бородатым талибановцам, и прочим бомжам. Сюжет здесь, откровенно слаб.

[h1]Геймплей.[/h1]
Линейный тир, как он есть, только в очень бюджетном варианте. Нас толкают вперед, а мы отстреливаем появляющихся бородатых фанатиков. Реалистичности в игре 0. Враги, даже на высокой сложности, в нас еле попадают, а сами дохнут от одного выстрела. Из пистолета в игре, можно подбить БТР. Если подбить БТР, выскакивает совет талибам, купить Росомак (польский бронетранспортер). Не будь в Афгане, американцев, поляки бы продали, кто же спорит, только вот сомнительно чтобы американский морпех, так уж заботился о польских производителях оружия. Всего в игре 12 миссий, на 5-8 минут, и проходится все, легко и быстро. Стоит иметь в виду, что есть кооп, и поддержка геймпада, но геймпад, здесь какой-то медленный, тормознутый и неудобный. Лучше играть с клавиатуры и мышки.

[h1]Графика и звуки.[/h1]
Картинка вполне норм, для бюджетного шутера, того периода. Единственный нюанс, есть как бы фишка, когда нас солнце слепит. По факту врагов, в тех местах где солнце, может быть не видно совсем, и это тянет больше не на фишку, а на баг. Озвучка обыкновенная. Бывает лучше, бывает хуже. Музыка, особо не запоминается.

[h1]Как итог.[/h1]
0% реалистичности, пафос, простенький геймплей. Плюс карточки, и все достижения часов за 5. Пройти можно, можно пройти мимо. Ничего интересного, эта игра из себя не представляет.

review:
I was quite confused with this game... it's an on-rails arcade cover shooter (like Time Crisis), 10 years after the genre died.  It's not in arcades, it's on PCs, where first person shooters have been around since the 1990's.   Most confusing at all is that a lot of effort seems to have gone into the game.

PCs don't usually have a "gun" controller meaning most players will use mouse and keyboard... in which case they might as well have made it an FPS. 

The graphics are quite decent but the game hangs if you alt+tab, which you will be inclined to do to help cope with the surreal existence of this game, intended for nobody.   Controls are okay but very simplistic.  You can do shared screen multiplayer... but you know, it's on PC so why not play over internet or on a LAN?

It's really a shame so much effort went into a game that just doesn't belong today.  It's less sensible than Dethklok making an album just for fish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112810429', 'num_games_owned': 2594, 'num_reviews': 578, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1522697858}
review:
Low-budget on-rail shooter, made for the consoles like Wii and PS3 primarily, but adopted for the PC as well. It wasn't anything special even right after the release in 2011, and now in Steam it is just a cheap, easy and relatively fast "platinum" and steam-cards-farm. 

I started it first in the midnight, and fell asleep after 4 levels (about 5-7 minutes each). Then I've played it in the bright day time, fully rested... but still had the urges to fall asleep a dozen times. You know, those really long winking like you're hearing some preaching again... in the middle of the shootout, where the bullets are flying at you. Boy, is this game so boring on purpose, or it is just the designers easy hand?

The story about some US soldier, believing he can do anything that really matters by shooting Afghans on their land... weak. The sounding actors through the missions were... not really acting. Well, all of the sound work was low-grade, actually, but those voices saying [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1350706282]"Good work!"[/url] are even worse in expression anything than your typical fake friends. A pity.

The visuals are somehow sub-par even in comparison with some PS2-era games. The colour gamma of Afghanistan mountains isn't too bright, sure, but here its just [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1350706317]brown and muddy[/url]. But the most troubling visual issue is the blooming sun, which makes some sequences a real [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1350706209]"find-the-hidden-object"[/url] game. Some Tango is shooting at you, but you can't see him thanks to that bloom effect. So you just shoot anywhere, making the cumulative achievement for 25K shots in total a bit closer...

Shooting mechanics and controls are dull and irresponsive. Like you're shooting at the wooden targets with some cheap plastic weapon made in PRC for kids.

As a quick summary, it is 4 points out of 10 in my book. The game's dull, the game's boring no matter how short it is. And it is 12 levels only, each is about 5 minutes long. Even the final boss, the Hind (Mi-24) chopper, eating your rockets for breakfast, will not hold you more than 8-9 minutes... Too generic that I would really recommend Heavy Fire: Afghanistan (or any other Heavy Fire title) for anybody except hunters for cheap achievements and steam cards. To be bought only bundled and with the good sale. Otherwise, you'll not return your money after selling farmed cards.

PS: Hiding from the 30mm autocannon under the chest-high concrete wall... and blowing the soviet BTR with the few spreads from your 5.56 assault rifle, with the developers commentary "they should have bought the Rosomak"... only in the Polish cheap shooter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068839161', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1517374945}
review:
That's it, this is the worst game I ever played on Steam. I wasted 15 minutes playing this, but I am determined to waste another 15 minutes to write this review and try to stop anyone who would ever consider wasting their time or money on this game.

Yes, I was aware this was a railshooter since the begining, I said, oh why not, this looks like "Rambo The Videogame" that game was moderately entertaining for two hours, and this one came within a bundle that did cost me 3 dollars, seems like a good investment. Why not? Well, Rambo is a really good game if compared to this.

Actually, comparing this to Rambo is unfair, it could be compared to Atari's 1995 Area 51. This game is actually more dated than that, as Area 51's 20 minute-long campaign featured better pacing and enemy placement, better guns, better voice acting, better soundtrack, and better sound effects than this. No, really, the gunfire sounds of this game are literally made with tin cans  being beaten with spoons. Please note, I am comparing this game to the experience of playing Area 51 on an emulator with the mouse. If I could actually have a Saturn or a Playstation 1 with a light gun and a big CRT TV, I would be really enjoying it right now.

Heavy Fire: Afghanistan can be compared to playing Duck Hunt on an emulator using the keyboard to control the aim. This is the level of entertainment we are talking about here. I really can't feel sorry for the developers who spent their time and money working on this, I understand how brutal the gaming industry is and how everyone needs to start somewhere, but this looked like a terrible idea since the begining, there are free flash games on Newgrounds made by students better than ths.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169700297', 'num_games_owned': 492, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1458582357}
review:
[h1] Heavy Fire: Afghanistan is an enjoyable on the rails shooter [/h1]
[b]Gameplay[/b]
You start off the game by creating a profile, and then you enter the world as a man named Will, who has just joined the marines, you go through a number of missions with you're new found self all while, shooting enemies, disabling traps, bombing grenades, hearing "TANGO DOWN!" a million times, shooting through planes and machines guns, as well spending skill points in your armory, which can upgrades things like weapons and health, which can really change how well you do in some missions, as you progress through your profile you earn in-game ranks! Which some are steam achievements! After you finish the 12 operations you unlock, almost a hardcore mode, where you run back through the missions with thier difficulty increased, called Vetaran mode.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[b]Combat System[/b] - The game has a highly enjoyable combat system, throwing grenades, destroying tanks and cars, having to pick up ammo drops and grenades, the on-rails part of the game is a hit and miss with some players but I find it really fun to have to know where the camera is and avoid shooting my own teammates.
[b]Controls[/b] -  The controls are quite easy to comprehend and arnt all over the place like some other games.
[b]Obstacles[/b] - The game is quite inventive with the obstacles it has to offer, the game uses even things like SUNLIGHT as an obstacle so that players cant see some enemies as well, and HF:A also has checkpoints in case you die!
[b]Graphics[/b] - The graphics arnt too amazing as the game was really originally made in 2011, but at that point in time these graphics would be considered well done, and I believe they are decent.
[b]Steam Integration[/b] - Having steam trading cards and achievements are a great edition to the game, that just add that little extra inch that makes the game even better!
[b]THE PRICE![/b] - The price of the game is only 3 dollars! And thats not even on sale or in a bundle! Its amazing the game isnt more because it really feels like a 10 or 15 dollar game!

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[b]Storyline[/b] - The story line in the game isnt too well done, most of the mission statements are short and not very exciting to the player, cut scenes arnt very amazing either.
[b]Setting[/b] - Where the game takes place, in fictional Afghanistan, has been done many times before this and is quite a common setting to see a shooter game bieng held.
[b]Voice Acting+Sound Effs[/b] - The voices arnt too well done and alot of people have problems with the gun shooting sounds, these arnt HORRIBLE to the game, but it isnt a pro thats for sure.

[h1][b]I would rate this game 7/10[/b][/h1]
Heavy Fire: Afghanistan is a great game. If you have played alot of shooters, and cant stand ontherails shooters I would suggest you not get the game because it isnt too far off your classic shooter. But obstacles like sunlight and machine guns, and the low price of the game, and the challenging aspects of the later gameplay really make this game amazing, $3 is a great price for 5+ hours of gameplay and even more if you want to delve into veteran mode. WIth 9 hours of gameplay I still havnt beaten the first 12 missions and I plan to keep coming back and taking on these missions and getting those achievements. I enjoy the game alot and Im sure you will too!

Still, while playing Heavy Fire: Afghanistan I felt really great. It's fun game, reminded me how much I loved on-rail shooters years ago and I feel kinda sad to see now that's almost dead genre. How many of these games we have on Steam? How many of these games come out in last few years? Yeah, kinda depressing for everyone who enjoys this genre. Sadly, this game won't make them more popular but it's always something nice to enjoy.

HOOAH!

It's not long, will be probably replayed by me few times, like many other games from this genre, and the price is great.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971341065', 'num_games_owned': 3377, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 413, 'last_played': 1455992810}
review:
A decent rail shooter with a reasonable storyline and good gameplay, although a bit on the easy side once you have the hang of the cover system and how to use it. There is a reasonable variety in the missions, in the open, villages, tunnels/caves, on a helicopter, in a tank, etc. so it doesn't become too repetitive.

The difficult ramps up reasonably well through the game, with an initial easy mode that unlocks a veterans campaign which is reasonably tough although it can be a bit checkpoint dependant - if you miss a health pack just before a checkpoint in a couple of places it can make it very difficult to advance without restarting the level. Other than that the checkpoints are fine, avoiding having to replay too much when you die, but not too close together so you have to get at least vaguely competent to advance (in VM at least).

The story is functional but fairly forgettable and generic, the on rails gameplay works fine here for me - you act reasonable sensibly, always having cover available (although it isn't usually 100% so you have to pick off a couple of enemies while in cover before you can reload and take on the rest of the scene one by one. You are a bit of a bullet sponge (especially once you have progressed and got the bonus health) but not to the point of immersion breaking - you do feel vulnerable to enemies, especially heavy machine guns and the like.

There are a few weak points though - repeatedly taking on BTRs with small arms (Technicals, sure), whereas at the opposite side of the scale a certain enemy that takes 10+ direct hits from a bazooka to kill seems unlikely. There are also quite a lot of quick time events where you are nearly crushed to death by a falling object or whatever, but following the instruction is optional - you dodge anyway, you just get extra points (and say "Hoo-ah!"). This leads onto the sound more generally - which is competent, but cliched and repetitive.

Overall this is a decent but fairly forgettable addition to the genre, recommended if you like this sort of "Time Crisis" gameplay, especially given it is not exactly expensive to pick up even when not on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041603555', 'num_games_owned': 1621, 'num_reviews': 454, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1581385295}
review:
Heavy Fire: Afghanistan is one of those "budget titles" that is easy to play, but left you rather empty. It is a rail shooter similar to old arcade game Time Crisis (yes, the one with the light gun) where you need to shoot enemies while popping in and out of cover. It plays fast, its graphics looks quite decent, but it is buggy and at certain stages, near to impossible to pass. Even at the price of only a few dollars, it is still hard to recommend. 

A rail shooter basically moves for you, stops at certain locations with cover. Duck behind the cover to reload, pop out to shoot (when enemy stops shooting). In this game, if the enemy has the red exclamation mark he's about to hit you, and your health bar only goes so far. The problem is when there are like 6 to 7 bad guys on the screen, 2-3 are shooting at the same time. There is no correct time to shoot (or is there?) As you clear area after area, with enemies poping out from close to far, you have to ration your shots carefully (one shot will kill the enemies) lest you fall back to your pistol. Yes, you do shoot pistols too. Occasionally you get to play with vehicle mounted weapons, same idea. 

The levels are quite decent, actually, look "reasonable" for the area they're depicting, villages, caves, mountain paths, city ruins, you get the idea. But enemies just... pop up, pretty much. 

The only powerups you get are ammo, health, and grenade (only ONE) which blows up enemies on one side of the screen. 

The game is buggy in that exiting the game can sometimes result in the game not starting the next time. The game's "launcher" will start, but as you click "play" both crashed to desktop, no error message. Sometimes change the video options and reinstall Direct X may cure it... until it happens again. There's seemingly no pattern to the crashes. 

All in all, there are better "rail shooters" around than this "topical" shooter rushed out to fit the news cycles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048998190', 'num_games_owned': 3397, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1441852133}
review:
[h1] Heavy Fire: Afghanistan[/h1]

Foi lançado no dia 29 de novembro de 2011 para o PC, porém só foi estar disponível no STEAM a partir do dia 15 de agosto de 2014. Ele é um jogo de tiro no estilo “on rails”, ou seja, não é preciso movimentar seu personagem a não ser para se esconder ou para as cenas de “action buttons” também conhecidos como “quick time event”. A não ser nessas partes você só precisa se preocupar em atirar nos seus inimigos, que são bem “burrinhos” e bem fáceis de se matar. Basta apenas um tiro que o inimigo irá morrer, não importa se é na cabeça ou no dedão do pé (sim, eu testei), não importa nem mesmo se está na dificuldade mais fácil ou mais difícil.

O jogo é criado pela mesma desenvolvedora do Rambo... (Sim... isso mesmo) Por isso é que ambos os jogos são bem “similares”. Eu com certeza não recomendaria o Rambo, acima de tudo por causa do seu preço, porém o Heavy Fire Afghanistan, custa apenas R$ 6 reais, e com as super promoções do STEAM, o jogo pode custar menos que aquele seu troquinho do pão.

São apenas 12 missões que você poderá concluir facilmente em apenas 1:30/2h de jogatina, entre as missões você poderá estar na pele do soldado, ou mesmo em um tank, helicóptero e é claro no famoso Hammer do exército americano.

A história do jogo... bem... é bem aquele estilo “Americanos invadindo o Afeganistão e matando todos os terroristas”, ou seja, basicamente a história é uma porcaria e nem compensa comenta-la. O som também é bem ruim, porém as músicas são até bem legais, os gráficos são bem “bonitinhos”, mesmo sendo um jogo “sem sangue”.

Na maioria dos jogos on rails, você deve atirar em itens pelo cenário em busca de outras armas, munição, vida etc. Nesse você só poderá encontrar packs de vida, granadas e munição. As armas são obtidas através de pontos que você vai ganhando ao completar as fases, esses pontos também são usados para dar upgrade em sua quantidade de munição máxima, sua barra de vida além das quantidades de granadas que você pode ter. Infelizmente o jogo possui apenas 4 armas + uma pistola.

Infelizmente o STEAM, apenas nos deixa dizer se “recomendamos” ou “não” um jogo. Eu não recomendo, assim como também não deixo de recomendar. É bem aquele tipo de jogo ruim, porém legal para se passar o tempo quando você já não tem nada mais para fazer da vida.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993777878', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1617763654}
review:
Um game simples de Rail Shooter que me lembrou clássicos como ''Virtua Cop'' ou ''Time Crisis'', não promete nada, é mais como um passatempo para quem gosta do estilo ou quer matar a saudade sem precisar re-jogar títulos antigos no videogame. A história gira em torno da campanha que os Estados Unidos fez durante a operação contra os terroristas no Afeganistão

Pros:
- O game retrata as batalhas reais no afeganistão durante a operação anti-terrorismo promovida pelos Estados Unidos.
- Durante algumas fases atiramos com um tanque ou de cima de um helicóptero, em outras também usamos metralhadoras giratórias
- Pra quem gosta desse tema (guerra no afeganistao) o jogo até que chega a ser bastante legal, ele é muito fiel aos locais reais.
- O game possui checkpoints, ou seja, morreu não precisa voltar tudo pro começo.
- Existe uma árvore de ''habilidades'' (como recarregar mais rápido, mais munição, mais granadas) que você pode comprar depois de determinadas fases, essa árvore permanece depois que você zera, podendo amplia-la.
- O game é curto, não enjoa, é possível zerar em 3 horas a campanha normal.
- Depois de zerado algumas coisas pequenas mudam quando você decide jogar a campanha no nivel mais dificil, como o período do dia (em fases onde era de tarde ficam de noite por exemplo) pra tentar nao ficar tao repetitivo.
- É possível jogar em cooperativo (apenas local).
- O game possui cards colecionáveis e o savegame funciona por ''cloud'' (ou nuvem se preferir) então se você zerou no nível normal mas nao quer jogar de novo agora, pode desinstalar o jogo e quando sentir vontade de jogar de novo voltar de onde parou.

Contras:
- Os gráficos são bem ruinzinhos, nas imagens o game parece lindo, porém se jogado ao vivo dá pra notar gráficos de 2007.
- Graficos um tanto quanto pesados se jogados com tudo no máximo, porém ele não dá lag, e sim a mira que acaba ficando pesada, estragando completamente o gameplay.
- Zerou acabou, o game não oferece nenhum extra, nada, é possível re-zerar no nível veterano..mas sinceramente, só faça isso se você quiser proezas ou mais cards.
- É possível 'trocar' de arma no game, o problema é que se você compra uma arma nova (usando
pontos) você automaticamente ''joga fora'' as armas antigas, não dá pra usa-las de novo.
- O game não traz um chefão nas fases como os games clássicos de Rail Shooter (só existe 1 chefe na ultima fase), algumas fases chegam a durar 5 minutos de tão curtas.
- O game é totalmente linear, não traz nenhuma opção de caminho ou coisas do tipo, até mesmo os quick-time events (aperte D em determinada situação) não fazem diferença nenhuma no fim das contas, nem mesmo matar os reféns solta algum diálogo diferente, nada.
- O game não possui nenhuma física, ao acertar os soldados eles fazem uma animação e caem (como no CS 1.6 por exemplo), não existe ragdoll e muito menos impacto de bala (tirando alguns pedaços de itens que quebram, mas é tudo padrão), e também coisas bizarras como destruir um carro de combate usando uma pistola.
- O som das armas é horrível, algumas parecem arminhas de chumbinho, é ridículo ver uma metralhadora pesada com um sonzinho de estalinhos.
- Jogar no veterano não significa que os inimigos estão mais inteligentes ou rápidos, a unica diferença é que seu dano é maior e a facilidade de levar tiros é mais alta, mas basicamente é igual jogar tudo de novo só por causa de 1 proeza.

A julgar pelo preço atual (6 reais) eu apenas recomendo para os fãs de Rail Shooters, se você não gosta nem um pouco do estilo e sempre que vai em um shopping vira a cara para as máquinas de tiro, não compre, porque é basicamente aquilo lá que Heavy Fire traz. Foi uma legal por reviver as experiência de jogos de tiro da minha infância, mas foi só isso.

there is a few things I really didn't like about this game like the camera always moving and if your firing any weapon when the camera just happens to move you will kill your own soldiers and I think I killed over 300. the fact that you couldn't move on your own and fire on your own at any target you wanted too. the gameplay is ok the graphics looked really sharp the story was almost like every other war game I have played, it kinda reminded me of one of the first Ghost recon games i played on the first xbox. but overall it's pretty easy till you hit veteran. I gave up on this game a long time ago and again decided to try it again and beat it because one of my friends was playing it. overall I liked it but didn't like a few minor things in the game but it's enjoyable if you can kill the narrator that constantly tells you when to jump or kill this guy or that guy but I couldn't ever kill him. still giving it a thumbs up because I can't get the last 3 achievements.

review:
[b]VERDICT:[/b] Heavy Fire: Afghanistan is a well polished, if short, rail-shooter with cover mechanics, unlockable weapons and equipment, and quick-time events.  

Full of quick-moving, adrenaline pumping firefights that occur in numerous fixed locations keeping you on your toes and forces you to take cover, acquire where targets are located, before shooting or blowing them up!  Limited ammo and explosives mean you are always looking to replinish your ever decreasing resources as the sequence of fights never let up until you complete the mission.  

Between missions you can update your equipment and weapons with up to twelve unlocks suchs as better weapons, larger ammo capacity or more grenades.  The enemy A.I. is competant enough to provide a challenge especially on Veteran difficulty.    

There isnt much of a learning curve and it doesnt last very long but in the few hours that you begin and end your mission you will get to experience a lot of fast paced and explosive action.   Being a relatively cheap game it punches above its weight..., I mean cost!  

It best feature is the way it keep the action moving forwards towards a conclusion just like a good novel.  Together with the excellent graphics, atmospheric sound and easy to use controls you get a great feeling of immersion.  It worst feature... well apart from its shortness.... Has to be the awful voice-overs during the mission de-brief... argh!! :) 

Will appeal to fans of the genre, achievement hunters or anyone who likes a cheap game.  If you dont like linear gameplay then avoid.  Personally I loved playing through it twice.


... MORE DETAILS BELOW ...


[b]01. GENRE:[/b] FPS Military themed, Rail Shooter w/ QTE

[b]02. SETTING:[/b] Modern Day, Afghanistan War

[b]03. STORY/BACKGROUND:[/b] You play the role of a soldier in a unit of the United States Army.  You are currently based in Afghanistan fighting a fictional skirmishes against insurgents.

[b]04. GAME MODES:[/b] Fourteen mission single-player campaign played in two difficulty settings - Rookie and Veteran modes, one after each other.  Play mostly as (grunt) foot soldier, with a very few missions as a gunner in armored vehicle or tank or helicopter.  These do a nice job of shaking up the action somewhat.

[b]05. GAMEPLAY/MECHANICS:[/b] Game mechanics couldn't be much simpler.  A series of linear firefights that take place in predetermined locations interspersed by sections of fluid automated movement linking each  location.  At each location enemies appear and try to shoot at you.  You in turn shoot/lob grenades, reload, get into cover.  Rinse and repeat.  Cover sometimes provides two or more options in the direction you choose.  This is something of a tactical decision as part of the screen remains open to enemy shooters so you may find you have to change cover position to remain safe.  Intersperced throughout every mission are a number of Quick-time events, introduced to shaken up the regular rhythm of gameplay specifically to keep you on your toes throughout the firefights.

Visual threats are indicated on screen so you can determine which enemy soldier is the biggest threat at a particular moment in the mission.  While additional audio indicators are used to indicated danger from heavy weapons.  Environmental elements such as smoke and sunlight are used to good effect to blind you from possible enemies lurking at a location.  While also adding an additional element of immersion to gameplay.  In addition the constant moving,  swaying, and ever changing line-of-sight, means you never quite have the time and occasion to take a perfect shot.  While the ever constantly changing camera angle greatly enhances the real threat of friendly fire taking place towards other members of your unit.

Difficultly is implemented though a combination of factors the speed at which enemies appear and shoot, enemy numbers and a reduction inresource replenhishments.  As you progress through each mission there are numerous resource refil icons to replenish ammo, health and grenades.  But you have to be quick.  If you miss them you must do without until the mission is completed.

There is an Armory screen that shows twelve unlockable weapons and equipment upgrades that makes the game easier and more fun to play.  

There is a ranking system that promotes you as you progress through the campaign twice; first on novice difficulty, followed by veteran mode.  This makes for a good learning curve as the harder difficult provides a decent challenge.  Completing missions gives points that total up towards a Ranking level.  The greater the combied scores the higher the rank.  The higher the rank the better the player.

[b]06. ENEMIES:[/b] Muhjahadeen and insurgents armed with AK-47s and RPGs.  Some heavy machineguns and rocket launchers mounted on pickup trucks, BTR armoured transports, and Hind helicopters.

[b]07. LEVEL DESIGN:[/b] Short, immersive levels. Uses a terrific range of locations so that you are never bored of the surroundings you find yourself in.  Camera sway and movement adds an extra dimension so you never quite feel in control of the situation.  Otherwise the threats are limited to mainly enemy soldiers and a number of heavy weapons or armored vehicles and helicopters make an appearance like end of level bosses.

[b]08. A.I:[/b] Robust if somewhat basic.  Then again this genre really doesnt need anything other than an A.I. that provides enough of a challenge for whoever is playing the game.

[b]09. CONTROLS:[/b] Excellent mouse and keyboard functions.  Especially pertinent is the mouse sensitivity options.  You may need this if you're mouse moves like a lead ballon as there is no light-gun for PC... :(  Whats a light-gun?  ^^

[b]10. GRAPHICS:[/b] Great.  Very colourful and adds to the immersion.

[b]11. SOUNDTRACK & AUDIO:[/b] Basic.  A single catchy soundtrack that eggs you forwards.  Some decent weapons sounds, shouts, screams, radio chatter and background explosions add to the immersion.

[b]12. VOICE ACTING:[/b] Not a big fan of the voice-overs in this game.  Felt like the voice actors were sub-par but thankly their use is limited only to the mission debriefs.

[b]13. CHALLENGE/DIFFICULTY:[/b] A breeze on Novice difficulty.  Actually challenging in places on Veteran difficulty.  The save checkpoints and environmental features add to the difficulty in veteran mode.

[b]14. PROBLEMS:[/b] No problems were encountered installing, running or playing this game.

[b]15. ACHIEVEMENTS:[/b] A good mix of achievements.  Mostly standard achieve x kills.  Complete mission y, etc... All easily obtainable by plaing through the campaign in Novice and  Veteran difficulty modes.  There are a few combo related achievements that may require a replay of a level or two.

[b]16. DLC:[/b] None.

[b]17. PLAYTIME:[/b] From five to ten hours to play the same campaign twice.

[b]18. LONGEVITY/REPLAYABILITY: [/b] Fans of the genre who dont mind replaying the same campaign can do so to better their score.  If you're an achievement hunter then you will play through the campaign twice and most likely complete all but one achievement during those playthroughs.

[b]19. ENJOYMENT/APPEAL:[/b] If you are fan of this genre or are too lazy to play a bon-a-fide FPS then this could be something you should consider.   Especially if you have a preference for modern day military themes set around the recent wars against religious fundamentalism.

[b]20. VALUE FOR MONEY:[/b] Perfect value for money.  If only it was a little longer.  A steal on sale.  An easy recommendation.

review:
I guess the concept is kind of interesting... many people (myself included) quite enjoy rail shooters in arcades. So... why not take the concept, but allow people to play in the comfort of their own home. Unfortunately, without the virtual gun, and with a not-quite-as-intuitive cover system, this rail shooter falls flat. Whether you play with a gamepad or keyboard and mouse - the controls are slow and sluggish, and the movements and animations just don't feel right. This is exacerbated by the Quick Time Events... probably one of my least favourite mechanics or gimmicks in any game - there is just no need for them, and they don't add anything to the gameplay experience except annoyance.

Additionally, considering this is on PC... the limitations of a rail shooter are woefully exposed when compared to the vast array of FPS games already on the market: you are directed where to go with no freedom at all except to duck in and out of cover and pop off a few shots. Even in FPS games with very linear levels, at least you can look around a room: not so in a rail shooter.

The audio for the game is pretty terrible, the weapons and explosions don't sound good at all. They sound generic, flat, and are of pretty low quality. The voice acting complements the poor soundtrack, with the voice actors not playing their part very well at all. This is compounded by the writing: not only is the overall plot of the game short and poor, but the dialogue is also poorly written, and is completely out of place.

Then there are the visuals, which look... reasonable, I guess. Not great, but not absolutely terrible like everything else about this game. Still, the ability to be completely blinded and be completely unable to see anything at all by sun glare and the excessive muzzle flash are both major weaknesses. Realistic perhaps, but definitely not conducive to a fun game.

For me, the only redeeming factor for the game is the progression, with the ability to pick perks after missions to customise your character.

Skippable. Very skippable.

[h1]5/10[/h1]
[h1]Purchase if heavily discounted[/h1]

[b]If you enjoyed this review,consider giving it a thumbs up![/b]

[h1]Pros[/h1]

+[b]Gameplay[/b]
Although a rail shooter is by no means an original idea this game does it well. Nothing special but also nothing particularly terrible when it comes to the on-rails gameplay.

+[b]Skill Tree[/b]
There is a semi-interesting skill tree in the game using points you get from ranking up. You can buy one of four new guns,ammo upgrades or grenade upgrades, etc.

[h1]Cons[/h1]

-[b]Shooting[/b]
The shooting in this game feels weak. The guns aren't particularly weighty and they feel more like pellet guns than a military assault rifle.

-[b]Repetitive Gameplay[/b]
Although this game is very average when it comes to the gameplay,the game gets very repetitive very fast. You end up almost falling asleep as you mow down seemingly endless numbers of terrorists.

-[b]Voice acting[/b]
The voice acting in this game is just bad. There isn't much to say other that the acting sounds incredibly forced and very unrealistic.

-[b]Graphics[/b]
This game looks like trash. The graphics are noticably bad as you go through many of the same environments over and over again constantly being forced to look at incredibly low-res textures.

review:
《Heavy Fire: Afghanistan》是一款典型的光線槍射擊遊戲，近年來以光線槍為主題元素的遊戲並不多見，大部分玩家可能已經忘記這種有著濃厚街機式風格的光線槍遊戲跟一般第一人稱射擊遊戲有何不同之處，光線槍射擊遊戲與第一人稱射擊遊戲最大不同之處就屬前者採用槍械形控制器進行瞄準射擊，並且以主角的視角為中心，大多數情況下玩家都不需要移動，僅須射擊敵人就能完成關卡。光線槍遊戲早在1930年代就有相關作品面世，當時技術尚未成熟，直到1990年代才出現風靡一時的光線槍遊戲《VR戰警》與《Time Crisis》，可惜這種類型的遊戲最終在千禧年時逐漸失去影響力，令筆者印象最深刻的事件就是前任台北市長陳水扁先生在千禧年前夕大量掃蕩電動遊樂場，直到十五年後的現在，筆者還是沒有機會在住家附近找到可以遊玩光線槍遊戲的街機店家。


非常可惜，這款由家機平台移植到個人電腦的光線槍射擊遊戲《Heavy Fire: Afghanistan》表現得十分差勁，先不談一款2011年出產的作品為何會在畫面呈現上倒退十年，詭異的遊戲平衡和懶惰至極的人物建模與載具建模設計也是一大敗筆，讓我們先來談談遊戲平衡性方面，不管玩家使用甚麼武器、運行甚麼難度，敵人只要被一發子彈擊中就會瞬間暴斃，不管你是拿著重型機關槍打爆敵人的頭或是用手槍擊中敵人的膝蓋，都會看見敵人嬌喘一聲後倒地不起，有沒有這麼誇張？就連擊中判定不同所造成的傷害多寡都沒有設計出來。其次讓筆者感到頭疼的缺點就是敵人種類不超過五種，從頭到尾會攻擊玩家的敵人只有複製人大軍阿富汗民兵，遊戲中期會出現兩種能被普通子彈打爆的裝甲車敵人，就連關卡頭目也是隨便打幾下就爆炸的直升機，遊戲難度可以說是毫無挑戰性。


《Heavy Fire: Afghanistan》是一款值得購買的遊戲嗎？答案是肯定的，能用不到一張百元鈔票的價格買到一款不需要接關投幣就能玩到完整內容的光線槍遊戲，怎麼想都很值得，本作確實讓筆者找回中學時期在電動遊樂場打接機的美好回憶，嘗試換個角度來看這款表現差勁的遊戲，如果提早個十五年前玩這款遊戲，本作在筆者心中的地位絕對會是前五名的神作，但是現今科技進步的速度非常之快，技術成熟的遊戲市場要的不是回憶，而是能吸引玩家購買的優質遊戲。很遺憾本作不是一款優秀作品，甚至連及格邊緣的普作都稱不上，它就像是暫時點亮黑暗的一根小火柴，帶給筆者短暫卻美好的遊戲體驗。

review:
アフガニスタンを舞台としたカジュアルレールシューター
自分もレールシューターって名前最近まで知らなかったけど
要はアーケードで置いてあるガンシューティングみたいなの事らしいですね
[h1][b]※間違ってもこのゲームはFPSではありません！！
　1番流通している1番目のトレイラーでパッケージ詐欺されないよう注意されたし！！[/b][/h1]
（ここだけの話、自分はこのゲームを手に入れる前は、FPSだと勘違いしてました…）

レールシューターとしての基本だけは出来ている
敵の撃つ銃の跳ね返りの音などを聞いて、今が安全か危険かなどの状況判断を行う事が出来る
弾薬もろもろのアイテムはちゃんと固定で配置されてて補給できるし、ちゃんと回収しないとクリア出来ないようになっているところもある
どうしても銃単体だけでは限界に感じられる所でもグレネード投げ込んだり、よく見るとバレル缶があって敵を一掃出来るかもしれない
[b]本当に本当に基本的な部分だけ[/b]は良く出来ている
ただチェックポイントシステムがあるのが返って
完全に位置覚えゲーである事と、運要素をより強めている部分があるとは思った…

特にこのゲームの良い見所を上げるとしたら、古臭さとカジュアル性を綯交ぜにして作ってあるところ
それこそ敵と背景が同化してぱっと見どこにいるか見えない（てか太陽まぶしすぎて敵が光で消えて見えねえ）
凄い昔のガンシューティングはこんな感じでワンゲーム終わって金ボったくられてるような悲しい気分にさせられてた
でもこの作品にはチェックポイントがあるため、気軽に死に覚えできる
しかもこのチェックポイント、そのチャプターのスタート地点まで撒き戻されるという事もなく
適度に折を見て休憩を入れれる用にできているので、かなりプラスポイント
このゲームの売りとも言えるカジュアルさが理不尽さの緩衝材となって、全体的には適度な難易度に感じさせてくれる
非常に1周目のリプレイ性は高く、個人的には高評価です

特に悪い部分としては前述の通り運要素の強いゲームであり、やり込む面白さも低いという事
敵が遠くに居るのに、やたら精度良く弾を当ててくる時もあれば
目の前に敵が居て連射してきてるのに全然当たらない時もあり、死ぬ要素が無さそうな所で油断するとゴリゴリ体力削れて死ぬし
今度はなかなかクリア出来ない所を、めんどくさいからってゴリ押ししたら、何故か被弾ゼロでクリアできたりなんかする
これもうよくわかんねえな
加えて弾薬と回復がプレイしてないのかってぐらいの配分で置かれてる
体力や弾が余りまくる所では、アイテムが馬鹿みたいに置いてあったりして無駄になったりするし
今度は敵の配置がいやらしかったり、弾がガリガリ持ってかれる所ではなかなかアイテム出なかったりするし
基本的なテストプレイやデバッグに関して手抜きというか、継続してプレイしてるとかなり粗が目立つ

あとは環境にもよるのでしょうが
カバーアクション後に敵を倒して、次のステージ移動前にリロードを入れたりすると
カバーアクションの後に次の移動アクションと連続してリロードも読み込まれて
一気にFPSが30下がったり、時にはプチフリ起こしてゲームが一瞬止まります
これはテンポ崩れるし、ちいとばかしストレスになり得るかも
それでもチェックポイントから気軽にプレイし直せるカジュアルさは
レールシューター慣れしていない人にもおすすめできるぐらいにバランスが取れてる
基本的な部分と、そこだけはバランスが本当に取れてる
というかほとんどのレールシューターはハイスコア狙うためにガチ廃人ばっかだからなあ…
個人的にはこれぐらいあっさりしてる方がやりやすい…
よく考えたら、基本的には時間制限有りとかって訳でもないし、急かされるようなゲーム性でもないんだよなあ～
本当に気軽にプレイはし易いです
現時点でのストア売値は300円と言うのもありますので、セールきたら暇つぶしにやってみても良いとは思います！
おすすめ！

ただこのゲーム実質シングルオンリーみたいなもんなので自分みたいにぼっちレールシューターじゃなくて
リアルで一緒にガンシューティング出来る友達とか居たり、この難易度で満足できない人が居るなら、おとなしくバイオとかタイムクライシスとかやってた方が良いかもしれん！
それだけは間違いないな！うん！

Saludos. 

Estamos frente a uno de esos juegos que, te hace recordar a los arcades de pistolas, tipo house of dead, time cop, Lethal Enforcers (1992 ), etc.. osea es un juego lineal, un rail (riel) en el cual vamos disparando según se mueva automaticamente los fondos.

nuestro unico trabajo es disparar y agarrar municiones, así como items.

+ lo bueno

+ gráficos cumplidores (te sentiras como aquellas arcades de la konami)
+ música y sonido.
+ jugabilidad esta bueno para pasar el rato solo o con amigos. (local offline)
+ la historia
+ logros y pequeños retos.
+ realmente no le veo nada malo, lo unico es que es. para un público determinado, aquellos que por nostalgía jugamos aquellos arcades, aunque el juego lo puede disfrutar cualquiera.

- lo malo

- un poco corto.


8/10 es un arcade shooter rail correcto. divertido muy sencillo. tal vez los niños o adolescentes de ahora, no lo encuentren muy divertido ya que es muy lineal, lo normal en los rails de los años 90s.


por el precio no esta mal. es corto pero re jugable. cuando venga un amigo o amiga de visita.

tecnicamente a mi no me dio problemas.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068604333', 'num_games_owned': 1203, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1428763416}
review:
Отзыв был бы положительным (скорее нейтральным), однако в игре есть огромный недостаток: совершенно ненужная сложность. Я прошёл все 11 операций, в некоторых местах было довольно сложно. Но! Началась 12, финальная операция. Больше половины я прошёл, но затем, промучившись 40 минут, так и не смог пройти одно место... Чекпоинты расположены очень далеко друг от друга, надо было чаще делать контрольные точки.

Что касаемо игры в целом:
Игра представляет собой... Хотя нет, это не игра, это кино с некоторыми действиями. В игре не надо даже ходить! Всё, что нужно делать -- стрелять, перезаряжать оружие и прятаться за укрытиями! А солдат ходит сам. Такое ощущение, что ПК превратили в консоль. 

Ну да ладно, значит упор сделан на стрельбу? "Наверное,  стрельба тут реализована на высшем уровне?!" -- ошибочно подумаете вы. Но нет, тут и стрельба реализована криво. Отдачи нет, тут вообще стрельба никак не связана с оружием. Просто по экрану водим кружок и нажимает кнопку мыши. Сама стрельба никак не чувствуется.  Прицеливаться тоже сложновато. Враги тоже странные, стоят в ряд и даже не думают прятаться. 

Но несомненный плюс в игре -- сюжет и графика. Миссий 12, и они вообще не копируют друг друга, много диалогов и перемещений. Графика для такого проекта хорошая, как и оптимизация: на моём желез всегда было 30+ fps.

Однако стоит ли брать игру за смешную цену, которая испортит вам нервы и в целом не является игрой? Я бы ответил "да", если бы смог пройти игру, потому что некое удовольствие я всё же получил. Но я скажу "нет", потому что остаётся очень неприятный осадок, когда приходится удалять игру в шаге от финала.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038669516', 'num_games_owned': 1850, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1426114939}
review:
Existen dos formas de hacer un juego de disparos on-rails:

La primera es la mas comun y clasica de ellas: un juego frenetico, un autentico no parar de enemigos, movimientos bruscos de camara y tiros por todos lados. Se trata de juegos en los que el componente principal es sentirse abrumado ante las oleadas constantes de enemigos, los cuales nos caeran encima por cualquier parte y provocaran que no podamos ni pestañear. Ejemplos claros son House of the Dead, The Lost World, Time Crisis, Gunblade NY o Vampire Night, entre muchisimos titulos.

La segunda difiere un poco de la primera pero no demasiado, obviamente seguiran apareciendo enemigos de manera constante pero, adicionalmente, se le dara importancia al entorno en el que estamos. Se trata de crear tension, de hacernos sentir la misma presion comentada en el primer punto pero tambien a traves de colocarnos en un espacio completamente hostil, de tal forma que a veces no dispararemos pero iremos viendo dicho escenario para hacer que nos preguntemos que nos atacara ahora o por donde. Ejemplos pueden ser Resident Evil: The Umbrella Chronicles, The Ocean Hunter, CarnEvil o Dead Space Extraction.

Pero aqui no estamos ante ninguno de estos casos. Heavy Fire: Afghanistan es un juego malo, muy malo, y lo dice alguien al que le encantan los juegos de disparos sobre railes. No me voy a meter en graficos o musica, pues obviamente no es una gran produccion ni pretende serlo. Voy a comentar lo que es la jugabilidad y de ahi todo lo que he escrito anteriormente.

Heavy Fire NO cumple ninguno de los dos puntos. No es frenetico, pues los enemigos suelen plantarsenos delante deseando recibir tiros y cuando se cubren les gusta asomar la cabeza a ver si se la volamos. Es cierto que no busca ser un festival de balas absoluto por el simple hecho de que te permite cubrirte, pero tambien esto lo dejan hacer otros juegos como Ghost Squad y no justifica situaciones estupidas como estar ante 6 enemigos, salir de la cobertura y que se hayan metido todos a la vez a recargar, dejandote varios segundos sin poder dar un triste disparo. Y tampoco nos pone en tension por el escenario, ya que una misera montaña afgana no es lo mismo que las localizaciones de Resident Evil, el fondo del mar o un parque de atracciones macabro. De hecho, una buena parte del juego la pasas viendo a tus compañeros marine haciendo el moñas por la fase gritando las 4 frases grabadas que tienen (hasta los... del "¡uh ah!" que se escucha cada dos por tres) en vez de disparando o mostrandote algo interesante.

Todo lo demas tampoco juega a su favor, la historia ni la he leido de lo aburrida que era, los enemigos eran siempre los mismos, los sonidos del arma parecian de juguete, lo he terminado en menos de 3 horas,...

Realmente un juego asi ni se merece un analisis en Steam, y aun menos uno extenso, pero me encantan esta clase de juegos y me repatea las narices que hayan desarrolladores que se piensen que con poco tiempo o presupuesto hacen un juego sobre railes que "es mas facil" y ya esta (ejem... Rambo...ejem), cuando requieren mucha maña para hacerlos divertidos e intensos (y rejugables, porque al terminarlo aparece un modo veterano pero a ver quien se vuelve a pasar esta bazofia...).

author: {'steamid': '76561197988060086', 'num_games_owned': 2126, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1423709089}
review:
Vamos invadir o Afeganistão na pele de um soldado ao melhor estilo Rambo de ser em um jogo shooter estilão arcade...

História: Invadir e fazer a limpa no afeganistão contra as forças terroristas.

Grafico: Gostei bastante do grafico ficou bem legal no meu ponto de vista. Agora para os mais exigentes que querem gráficos de ultima geração que cresceram tomando leite ninho e assistindo malhação, esses sim vão estranhar os gráficos.

Jogabilidade: Bem traquila, você atira, taca granada, controla a mira, o movimento de cover pra baixo, esquerda ou direita, alguns movimentos rapidos de ação para desviar de alguma coisa, ou pular obstaculos, os movimentos para avançar no jogo são automaticos, lembra aqueles shooters arcades antigos. Sistema de upgrade a cada 2 fases passadas você aumenta algo para melhorar o personagem (arma, municao, vida, granada e o recarregamento da arma).

Tem um sistema de patentes que aumenta conforme você pega conquistas.

O jogo em si é bem curto em 2 horas eu passei a campanha normal e abri o modo veterano.

Acredito que o ponto alto do jogo é a ação de estar atirando o tempo todo e o soldado interagindo com você na hora de atirar, dar cover, seguindo os companheiros de guerra e os dialogos entre os personagens.

Fui ao delirio na missão de escoltar os carros e tanques com um helicóptero invencivel e de munição infinita, é simplesmente fantástico...

Aqui está um ótimo jogo de tiro e ação para você passar um tempo e platinar.

Recomendo !!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198003360937', 'num_games_owned': 1547, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1447910440}
review:
Ooh, not a good game. It's an rail shooter, which will put a lot of people off. There's nothing wrong with rail shooters and games like Time Crisis, Virtua Cop and Ghost Squad are loved by the people who like them. And I do like me a bit of Ghost Squad.

Many people don't like rail shooters because all they do is point and click, but there can be subtlety to them like Ghost Squad's choice system and Virtua Cop's hidden items and difficult bonus kills. Heavy Fire Afghanistan (HFA) has none of that.

For starters, it's too easy. You're never really under threat. I cruised through the first two levels, barely taking a hit. I did run out of ammo once, until I realised that one hit was enough to take down any enemy. Even the cover system is barely necessary. You get an exclamation mark above the head of everyone who is about to shoot, so it's easy to just stand there and shoot everyone. Hmm.

The game is clearly a lazy port and constantly refers to Xbox controls. There's even a bit of laziness on the interface - you can see the edges of button pics and interface items. Nothing terrible, but it shows the lack of care in the port.

I'll probably play this a couple more times before I completely forget I own it. I got it as part of a bundle and so it's kind of okay for that, but it's still a forgettable, easy, empty experience.

review: Heavy Fire: Afghanistan is a on rails shooter developed by the same people who did Rambo the video game but will this be a better game than that or the same mess ? In Heavy Fire: Afghanistan you play as Will who is re telling his war stories that we relive and play through shooting our way through a war. So how is this game ? This game is bad and thats pretty much all i can say about it. Now as on rails shooter theres not much to say about it. You are put on a track and as soon as you clear out a room of enemies you progress on a track. But the game has many problems. Lets start off with the good. The game has pretty fun gameplay but even that wears out very fast. But now for the bad and theres alot to say here. The game is buggy and the hit detection is horrible. The game looks okay but the resolution problems really affect the game since its hard to tell where the enemies are when everything looks the same. The game is easy and also really short. The story is abysmal. The game also has one big problem. You have to make an account for the game if you want for the game to save. If you dont make an account the game will delete all youre progress. review:
Это - FPS для лентяев, котоые не любят нажимать кнопки ходьбы. 
Шучу. На самом деле довольно хорошая игра, представляющая собой интерактивный тир,в котором вас очень быстро передвигают от мишеней к мишеням, и вам нужно очень быстро реагировать и отстреливать противника.
Плюсы : 
+ Динамичная, задорная, привлекательная пострелушка.
+ Удачный порт с консолей
+ 12 интересных миссии, также доступно дерево апгрейда, открывающееся после прохождения миссий.
+ Хорошая графика. Все приятно смотрится. Взрывы конечно не на 10 баллов, не смотрятся нормально.
+ Вас не поставят в чистом поле против врагов, есть возможность использовать укрытия (кроме стрельбы на ходу, там вы гол как сокол). Перебежки, развороты и различные элементы создают впечатление полноценного шутера, только будто ходите не вы, а кто-то другой.
Минусы :
- Звуки выстрелов далеко не соответствуют реальным, но, не особо ображаешь внимание.
Вокруг вас все время что-то происходит. Убили противника, где-то бабахнула бочка, сбили вертолет, союзник откачивает раненого ... и все это без вашего участия. Иногда игра смахивает на динамичный фильм. Еще бы стреляли за вас, и можно было бы сидеть и смотреть как кино. Дешевое кинцо, но с динамикой и спецэффектами.
P.S. Для таких игр не хватает пистолета, как был для Денди. По уткам стрелять. Бородатым вооруженным уткам.

review:
Heavy Fire: Afghanistan es un juego de acción sobre railes que no innova en nada. Encontramos todos los tipos de elementos comunes a este género; barriles de explosivos, cajas de madera con munición, barra de vida... Esto no es malo, pues funciona, pero logicamente lo convierte en un juego que pasa sin pena ni gloria y el cuál nadie recordará en unos años.

A esto que he comentado anteriormente hay que sumarle unos cuantos contras que le pesan también bastante al juego. Lo primero es que la inmersión en su argumento es malísima; no me enteré casi de nada exceptuando que tenía que matar Afganos por doquier. Otro punto negativo es su escasísima duración; nos lo podremos pasar facilmente en 2 horas, pues cada uno de sus 12 niveles se tarda de media 10 minutos en superarlos -que cierto es que en la mayoría de los juegos sobre railes suele ocurrir-.

Yo lo jugué en su versión de Steam pero está claro que este juego se podría disfrutar mucho más en su versión de Wii o PS3 en donde podremos usar el Wii Mote o el PS Move a modo de arma. Apuntar con el puntero del ratón le resta muchísima dificultad.

Sinceramente, si eres un amante de los juegos sobre railes, supongo que lo disfrutarás, pero en todo caso, yo no pagaría más de 1,5€ por él en ninguna de sus versiones.

review:
I wanted to love this game, but I don't think I can suggest picking it up.  The on-rails, arcade-style gameplay was my narcotic throughout grade and middle school; that's transferred over well enough.  I forgive it for the uninspiring story, pitiful voice acting, and Stormtrooper-grade A.I.

The fact that guns barely make a sound troubles me most.  A close second is the fact that you seem to swivel around on a turntable whenever you're moved down the "rail."  I wasn't expected spectacular quality, but goodness, this is awful.

"Shoddy" encapsulates Heavy Fire in a word.  It's not worth the bargain on a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009459416', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1419123955}
review:
First off, let's get the elephant out of the room: this is an on-rails shooter. The developer made no attempts to hide the fact, so if you read a review from someone who is particularly irate about this, they probably lack reading and visual interpretation skills.

Heavy Fire: Afghanistan is the guiltiest of pleasures. It's more linear than a triple-A shooter, has a setting that's about as overdone as that pizza I left in the oven last night, and quick-time events that would make David Cage blush. And yet, between the story and dialogue that fumbles with both the English language and basic military jargon, guns that look and sound like they were assembled from the imagination of Call of Duty-playing seven-year-olds, and graphics that give off a "Medal of Honor 2010 played on a toaster" vibe, this game... is pretty fun.

It's a basic on-rails shooter that doesn't really do anything wrong gameplay-wise, in an environment that doesn't do anything new, setting-wise. You'll brease through it in two hours, although there's a "Veteran" mode which amps up the difficulty once you've beaten the main story. You could do a lot worse with five dollars... but you could also do a lot better.
